all_paragraphs: A crucial theorem that sits in the background of inferential statistics, without which inferential statistics has no relevance. It assists in hypothesis testing, regression analysis, and other analytical techniques.
Yes I am talking about “THE CENTRAL LIMIT THEOREM”

It states no matter how the population distribution is, as the sample size (n) of the samples derived(with replacement) from the population increases, the distribution of the sample mean or sum approaches a normal distribution.

Numerically, means of random samples drawn from any population distribution with mean µ and standard deviation σ will have an approximately normal distribution with a mean equal to µ and standard deviation of σ /√n.
Suppose there exists a population of males on Planet ‘X’ and we want to estimate the mean of the population height, how do we do it:
1. Compute the mean with whole population data?
2. Estimate with samples using Central Limit Theorem?
Choice 1 is impractical as no one possesses the amount of time and effort required for such Magnus activity. Choice 2 it is, let’s see how it works visually:

Suppose the distribution below has the data of Height (Males) — the entire male population on Planet X. Why is it normal? Because anything measurable/countable under chance/random causes will always follow a normal distribution curve. Even if it was under the influence of assignable causes(not a normally distributed curve), still the central limit theorem would have held true. For now, we are taking this example for understanding the gist of this theorem. It is not practical to measure the height of all males and will try to infer the population mean with samples.
Now we have 5 self-proclaimed estimation experts to estimate the mean with varying sampling choice:

Remarks by the estimation Lord here are displaying negative sentiments about the estimation expert and his choice of sample size (n=2). The distribution of the 10 estimated means is also far away from a normal distribution. Now it’s the turn for the next expert in line:

Remarks by the estimation Lord here are displaying somewhat positive sentiments about the estimation expert and her choice of sample size (n=10). I think I am able to put some relevant ideas of the central limit theorem in your mind now — as the sample size increases, the estimation of population mean gets closer and closer to the actual population mean with decreasing dispersion/spread alongside a shape replicating a normal distribution (*of the sample estimated means). According to this, which one among the 03 leftover estimation experts will have the best estimate of the population mean with high confidence (low spread/dispersion of estimated means)-
Yes, it is the last guy (doppelganger of Einstein). Introducing the numerical definition of CLT with the estimation of the same guy:
Where σ is the standard deviation of the population distribution & n is the sample size of the derived sample from the population

Estimated Means distribution has a mean(*also known as a mean of estimated means) approximately equal to the actual population mean with very low spread/dispersion which depicts good confidence of estimation.
This spread/dispersion of sample estimated means is also known as the “Standard Error”.
So one crucial insight is — higher the sample size, the lower the spread of the sample estimated means which leads to higher confidence in estimation.

Now we have come to the end of this blog, I hope by seeing an unconventional & simple visual exercise you have understood the basic idea behind the application of the Central Limit Theorem.
The major takeaway is ‘everything we do in the scope of inferential statistics(making estimations using samples from a population), Central Limit Theorem is always present in the background’.
